results.title: The Gambler Dostoevsky
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Risk”.
A play based on Dostoevsky’s novel “The Gambler”. Dostoevsky lived his life on the edge of disaster, financial, political and emotional, and the story is about his gambling and about his loving. Dostoevsky’s widow, Anna, recalls her relationship with this complicated man.

group_siblings.title: Jackson Pollock What Kind of Risk

results.title: Jackson Pollock What Kind of Risk
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Risk”.
Jackson Pollock (1912-1956) was the leading exponent of what is usually called Abstract Expressionist Art. Charles Harrison examines a number of Pollock’s paintings, and discusses how they were made and what they represent. Includes some film of Pollock himself working on a painting in 1952

results.title: Kings and coolies
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Christine Olsen, AFFC and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Riding the tiger”.
Riding the Tiger Series. Even though the Indonesians rid themselves of Dutch colonisers in 1949, the new economic order developed by the military has replicated the vastly unequal distribution of wealth that has plagued Indonesia’s modern history: now, however, the wealthy few are Indonesian not European. This episode examines Indonesia’s feudal past and the impact of European colonisation on the Indonesian population. The maintenance of feudal authority by the European colonisers is one of the roots, this video claims, of the military’s successful suppression of democracy in contemporary Indonesia.

results.title: Riding the tiger
results.brief_description: Riding the Tiger is a series examining the history of Indonesia since the struggle for independence in 1945. The series focuses on the military organisation of Indonesian society and on the consequences of colonial rule on Indonesian politics and culture.
results.description: Riding the Tiger is a series examining the history of Indonesia since the struggle for independence in 1945. The series focuses on the military organisation of Indonesian society and on the consequences of colonial rule on Indonesian politics and culture.

results.title: The New order
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Christine Olsen, Zex AFFC and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Riding the tiger”.
Riding the Tiger Series. In this episode we trace the struggle between the military, the communists and the rich landed Muslim gentry to control the economy of the newly-formed nation. In 1965 the tensions between the various factions exploded: President Sukarno was replaced by military general Suharto and half a million communists and “communist sympathisers” were executed. Since 1965 the military has developed a one-party dictatorship which actively encourages its civilians to allow the dictates of business (both local and foreign) to take precedence over all other aspects of life. The last part of the video examines the conflict between Indonesia’s economic growth and its governments’ consistent human rights abuses.

results.title: Freedom or death
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Christine Levy, AFFC and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Riding the tiger”.
Indonesia has one of the most militarised and organised populations in the world. From a very young age Indonesian civilians undertake training in various forms of youth groups, neighbourhood councils etc. which are all linked to the military government. In this episode the strength and power of the military is traced back to the feudal roots of Indonesia; to the resistance movements against the Dutch colonisers; the role of the Japanese army in training the Indonesians; and the underground resistance of the late 1940s which overthrew first the British occupiers of the country, then the returning Dutch administration.

results.title: The Bottom Rung
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rich World Poor World”.
This program reports from Bangladesh, Tanzania and Brazil and highlights the extreme poverty there. It poses the question ‘Can the gap between rich world and poor world ever be closed?’

results.title: A New Deal?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rich World Poor World”.
About 10000 people around the world die every day from lack of food. Are we really heading for global disaster? What can the world do to help itself? This and other questions about world poverty are discussed
